We live in times of great uncertainty. I cannot truly answer any of the above questins, but the last one is one I feel most able to answer.

Now
I'm sorry I've not been updating for a while.

I hope you got your decks and have had many chances to enjoy the games.

Some folk have been making their own games and some of them have been submitted to the website. Maybe you had a chance to try the . I was really happy to hear Rahdo say how much it was enjoyed with Jen. Maybe you can also try it with your partner or a friend you do 2-player games with.

Wibbell and Grabbell are personally still my favourites. At Essen, I played Coupell over 200 times and I was still enjoying it (although I started giving myself secret handicaps). I often play Wibbell and Grabbell with my housemates and Micol actually often beats me at Grabbell!

The website is firmly in place but is still very much 'in progress'. And now I'm starting on the next step of my plan.

Mailing missions
Hopefully you have all received your Wibbell++ decks. It was 3 weeks since I posted them and I heard about arrivals in Australia. If you haven't gotten your decks, did you fill out the survey?

Get in touch if there are any problems. (Replying below, or messaging me.)

Last wednesday, I sent out all the packages to those who had pledged for a game and fulfilled their surveyes. On Thursday, I sent out the packages to those who had pledged for 4 signed copies. On Friday, I sent out the packages to everyone who had pledged for 1 signed copy.

A couple of copies were handed to folk on Sunday. One copy was wrapped up specially (due to a leaky mailbox) and sent on Monday, along with a few more parcels to folk who had filled out their surveys later.

Those within the UK will probably already have their copies of Wibbell++. Those in Europe will probably get it in the next few days if they haven't already. Those in USA/Australia/China/Singapore will probably have to wait another week.

It's been lovely going through the packages, imagining all the fun that the decks will bring around the world.

I'm lucky in that the tuckboxes, inside a padded envelope, still just-about count as a large letter. It helps keep costs lower (and the domestic charges relatively cheap), compared to something even a few mm wider.

Sadly, posting abroad will never be cheap. To send it to USA, the cheapest option is £4.75. I could ask a fulfillment company to do it, which would lower the price by about 10p. But then I'd have to first send them the games. And I wouldn't be able to customise your envelopes or put in the little comics, which I hope bring a smile to your face.

campaign.story:
Dale of Merchants 2 can either be played fully on its own or combined with the original Dale of Merchants. The game expands the gameplay possibilities and variance of the first one. You are one of the animal-shaped merchants competing to become the next Trade Master in this highly adaptive deck building game. The game supports 2–4 players and playing time is around 20 to 30 minutes.
  Every card can be used in multiple ways providing the players with tough and meaningful choices. Do you give up a chance to use a splendid action in favor of getting even more astounding cards? You can't win the game without letting go of your cards.
The goal of the game is to finish up your merchant stall before anyone else. The first player to do so, wins the competition and is chosen as the new Trade Master in the free trade city.
With 6 different decks, the replayability of the game is extremely high. You get fresh gameplay by mixing various decks from game to game. The decks from Dale of Merchants 2 can be played with the original Dale of Merchants which brings the total amount of decks to 12! This introduces a whole new set of combos and possibilities.
    The funding goal is set so that we can produce the game with extremely high quality components, including heavy card stock with linen finish. These cards are meant to last! We include the whole experience, if we reach our funding goal
This is why the stretch goals are mostly about small improvements to the game – it is complete and full without any of them. That being said, we do have one huge stretch goal, if we pass our last campaign's funding.
All stretch goals marked with "Promo!" are included for free in each pledge level containing a physical game. You'll receive one of these for each copy of Dale of Merchants 2. These promos will be available after the campaign for additional price in limited quantities.
The game is ready and heavily playtested. About 95 % of the artwork for the game is and ready for print. We will finalize everything during and after this campaign, taking backer feedback into account. This will allow us to minimize delays and deliver the game to all the backers as reliably and fast as possible.
Retailers interested in the game should contact us directly by a private message or by email (info@snowdaledesign.fi).

Fulfillment: 
Kickstarter fulfillment can be a frightening prospect for a first-timer. That’s why we asked for help from experienced and successful developers on Kickstarter. This is what turned us on to the “China method” (Shipping directly from china to fulfillment centers around the world)

Our method is not new and has been used successfully by other developers. Our fulfillment company has the experience to deliver your games, and just to be sure, we will have some backups to ensure 100% fulfillment!

Finally, we are keeping the rewards simple. We do not want to take more time than necessary to complete the shipping. We want you to get the game as soon as possible!

campaign.story:
Super Hazard Quest is a tabletop game inspired by the classic age of video game side-scrollers.
I know... you’ve probably heard that before, right?
8-bit art and retro inspired games are pretty popular these days. But Super Hazard Quest not only references classic video games, it plays like one too.
Heroes build and explore an ever-changing, randomly generated level. Along their adventure, they’ll discover new items, tackle enemies and beat powerful bosses.
But their most dangerous threat are other heroes. Who will be the first player to defeat the final boss and take the glory?
It’s all the fun of multi-player retro gaming without ever having to blow into a cartridge! 
Stealth Ninja
What's in the box!
Game consists of: 
54 Item Cards 
26 Dungeon Cards 
2 Instructional Cards 
8 Character Tokens 
32 Hazard Shards 
16 Crystal Shards 
Instructional Manual
EXPANSIONS
Our "New Bosses" expansion features 5 new Dungeon Cards to expand the game board further. New Mini Bosses means a new way to win and a boss prize that can give players another advantage. This expansion also features an completely new Underwater level with artwork not seen in any of the original dungeon cards.
The “Warp Pipes" expansion also features 5 new Dungeon Cards to expand the board. These cards put a clever twist on navigating the Dungeon through Warp Pipes. If two or more Warp Pipe Dungeon Cards are out on the table, the player can jump into one and come out of another, no matter where it is on the table. It's a whole new way to get around.
Finally, the "New Item" expansion offers 16 new Item Cards, some of which have powerful new properties that can change the Dungeon as a whole.
All expansions are great and change the game in a different way. Bosses bring a challenge, warp pipes bring speed, new items bring more competition
Elf of Legend
Super Hazard Quest is a board game without a game board. How is that possible, you ask?
Well, the board (or dungeon, as we call it) is modular, made up of jumbo sized Dungeon Cards. Each card represents a room. Shuffling these cards before each game ensures no two dungeons will ever be the same.
All heroes begin on the same Dungeon Card and take turns exploring. When a new room is entered, a new Dungeon Card is drawn from the top of the deck and placed. Thus, the Dungeon builds as the players explore.
Dungeon Card
You’ll notice a flag on the left hand side of most Dungeon Cards. This is called a Checkpoint. Players must move between these Checkpoints during their turn. They may move as far as they can, but their turn will always start and end on a Checkpoint.
Some Dungeon Cards have enemies standing between Checkpoints. We call these Combat Hazards. There are four different kinds and each one requires a corresponding Action in order to pass. The name of this Action is listed above each Combat Hazard.
Completing a dungeon also requires an Action. We call these obstacles Direction Hazards and there are also four, representing up, down, left and right travel.
All 8 Hazards
Use of these eight Actions are granted by Item Cards. Players always hold five Items in their hand and may play as many as they wish per turn. Each Item Card explains what Actions it grants (or whatever other tricks it performs).
At the beginning of their turn, players slide their hero token to the bottom of the Checkpoint and begin moving along the floor of the Dungeon. With each Hazard encountered, the player places the Item used face up on the table. All used items are discarded at the end of the turn and new Items are drawn to replace those used.
Hidden among the Dungeon Cards is the game’s Final Boss: The Scrambler. The first hero to defeat him is the winner. But the Scrambler is a powerful monster and his only weakness is a mystical Crystal.
The Scrambler, and the Crystal Shards that defeat him.
Crystals are also hidden among the Dungeon Cards, guarded by mighty Mini-Bosses. Defeating a Mini-Boss requires a combination of four Combat Actions. But conquering these foes will earn the player a key to victory.
The first player to reach a Scrambler while holding a Crystal is crowned ultimate hero and winner of the game. But tread carefully… Other heroes may have tricks up their sleeve…
FULL SET OF RULES CAN BE FOUND BY CLICKING HERE
HERE IS SOME GAMEPLAY FOOTAGE WE SHOT!
Kung Fu Champion
Evil Sorceress
Mad Scientist
 In almost every way, Super Hazard Quest is a finished product. Multiple prototypes have already been printed and hundreds of players have taken part in play-throughs. So why are we on Kickstarter?
Events that we've had success with Super Hazard Quest play tests.
Well, now we need to print and get the game to players! While our prototypes look great, they’re really expensive. In fact, they’re so expensive it’s unrealistic to sell them at a competitive price in the table-top game market.
After crunching some numbers and getting a few quotes, it’s clear that a mass print from a larger company would drastically reduce the price. But while the cost per unit is much cheaper, we’ll need to print a minimum 1500 copies - and that adds up to be a lot more than we have. Kickstarter not only allows us to raise this money, it also ensures that the demand for our game is there. Pre-ordering your copy not only gets you the game, it helps toward our print, which can help other people get copies of the game too!
And while we’re at it, there are a few artists who have done us favors to make this game possible. We’d love to reward their good nature by paying them for the great work they did. A further breakdown of where each dollar will go is below:
Floaty Princess

If you missed the Kickstarter you can head here or to this very average website to keep up to date with Vivarium and find out when it hits retail shelves!


We are funded! Thanks to your support Vivarium is real and each backer will receive one beautiful copy of Vivarium!
Now on to the stretch goals!
We've unlocked the extra Event cards and a custom plastic insert for the game box. Next up is increasing the size of the tokens! We're almost there!
Each copy of Vivarium will include an extra 4 Event cards bringing the total to 24. Committed players will be able to play 6 year games. :)
Each copy of Vivarium will include a custom plastic insert inside the box to hold and store all the components. 
All the tokens in Vivarium will be at least 20mm in diameter allowing them to be more easily handled but still able to fit onto the map.
All of the game tiles, the player boards and the tokens will be made with heavier cardboard stock making them harder to move and increasing their overall quality. 
All the cards in Vivarium will be 300gsm black core paper.
If this goal is reached then a special victory track will be included in each copy of Vivarium so that players can more publicly track everyone's Fitness. This has been a hotly requested item that requires some rejigging, art work and added costs, but I have plans to integrate with some other components to conserve table space and make it work efficiently with the rest of the game! 

GO TEAM! 
Vivarium is a strategy board game for 2-5 players where you begin the game as a species fighting for survival inside a new environment. Equipped with just your instincts and fears, you must utilize your species unique abilities and adapt in order to survive. 
By acquiring new cards -
 Claiming territory -
Enduring natural disasters -
Defending the Oasis and completing objectives you can increase your fitness to survive. 
The player with the most fitness at the end of the game wins! 

Vivarium has 8 distinct species, a modular game board and varied seasonal events that ensure every game is unique and layered with strategy.  

Do you have what it takes to survive?
 Vivarium's box is loaded with lots of pretty components, check it out!
 That's a lot, right!?
You can see what Undead Viking has to say about Vivarium here:
NVS Gameplays very graciously did a PnP preview of Vivarium, have a look at what they thought below:
You can also check out this comprehensive review from the Australian Tabletop Gaming Network. :)

 The Sit Down Standard very graciously did a preview of a PnP version of Vivarium. Check it out:
Simply put -
IT'S A LOT OF FUN!
This is it. This is possibly the only chance you'll be able to acquire Vivarium. There's always a chance of future print runs, but no guarantees so back it while you can!
It's beautiful. The art and design that's gone into Vivarium really shines. The illustrations on all the components are top notch and really capture the beauty of the natural world.
It's a really good value proposition. $60 AUD gets you the game for a price well below MSRP. Vivarium is huge, not only are there a lot of components in the box but the replay value is massive. You're saving money by backing now AND helping dreams come true! 
It sends a message. The story, theme and even some components of this campaign (see Rewards) have the potential to send a message to Vivarium's audience. About the beauty of nature, and its fragility. The more people that engage with Vivarium, the more people there are thinking about animals and hopefully appreciating them. 
Vivarium needs you. The more people that get behind Vivarium, the better off it is. More backers unlocks more stretch goals and ultimately makes Vivarium as good as it can be.
Vivarium is a strategy game with high replay value. It combines dynamic deck building with resource management, combat, and territory control. Each game creates a unique game filled with tough decisions and harsh consequences. 

Here is a link to the current rule book for Vivarium.

It is still a work in progress and parts of it may be subject to change.
If you have any feedback please let me know!
The more eyes on it the better. :)

You'll have to use counters or dice to track resources rather than use dials and naturally the experience will be somewhat diminished but this is a great way to get a feel for the game before backing.

*If you select the 'Keystone Collector' pledge level and are in Australia, the US or the EU you can add an extra copy of Vivarium to your pledge for $60 AUD. 
You do not need to pay extra shipping for your 2nd and 3rd copy.
This way you can receive up to 3 copies of Vivarium, all covered under your initial shipping cost. 

Unfortunately, this is only doable in the above regions and you will have to pay another game's worth of shipping if Vivarium is not being shipped to one of the above regions. This also applies if you are adding a 4th copy to your pledge. 

You can add more copies of Vivarium to your pledge by clicking the 'Manage Your Pledge' button. You'll then have the option to change the Pledge Amount. Add $60 AUD for each additional copy plus the appropriate amount of shipping for your region per copy. 
First things first - Vivarium will be shipping from within respective regions meaning that the cost you pay now is all you have should have to pay. All customs and freight fees should be handled before shipping to backers and all possible steps will be taken to ensure this happens.
Shipping will always be a challenge, and for a first time creator, it's even more daunting. In order to reduce risk, I am utilizing the skills and knowledge of experienced fulfillment companies and keeping the process simple. 

Utilizing the Stonemaier method, one company will be handling Australian fulfillment, another company will handle American fulfillment and a third company will be handling Europe, Canada and the rest of the world.

I've received quotes from lots of companies and these 3 provide the most cost effective service while also granting peace of mind that Vivarium will be fulfilled in an efficient, secure and professional manner. 

Vivarium is a large game, weighing in at around 1.5kg. With packaging it will be closer to 2kg as such I will be absorbing $10 AUD of each game's shipping costs leaving your shipping costs quite competitive.
Corey Le Mesurier is the designer of Vivarium with 5 years working in the board game industry and even more in the general gaming industry. Vivarium is the first game designed by Corey, and hopefully not the last. 

Michael Roberts is the primary illustrator for Vivarium. We have him to thank for all the beautiful images we see on the cards, the box, the player boards and the map tiles. Michael helped bring Vivarium to life, giving form and substance to all the species and the environments in the game. This was Michael's first time illustrating for a board game, and frankly, it didn't show. He smashed it out of the park.

http://drawcrowd.com/armedrobot

Rose 'Rocky' Hammer created the symbols you see on the cards, designed all the tokens and was a constant source of advice and expertise on the graphic design of Vivarium. Rose has heaps of experience illustrating animals and was the main illustrator for another board game, Dragon Racer. 
You can see more of Rose's work here: 
http://rockyhammer.com/
https://www.facebook.com/rockyhammercreations/

Alexis Sabarre, Chevelle Grey, Krishna Sharma and Felice Sciaraffia all contributed to the design and development of Vivarium in various ways. You're all awesome!

Vivarium is the work of many hands. It is the collective advice, imagination and time of so many people. From all the wonderful play testers to everyone who simply said 'Hey Corey, how's your game going?', we have you to thank for this project being here. Sincerely, thank you.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The art and graphic design for Vivarium is done. Aside from minor changes and polishing of the text Vivarium is close to print ready. This means that as far as design goes, the hard work is pretty much done.

I've produced two waves of prototypes through the manufacturer that will print the final copies of Vivarium so I've had time and experience in file preparation and testing the components. The manufacturer has provided great quality components and I'm sure the final product will look absolutely beautiful. This process should not experience much delay due to the files being for the most part already prepared. However, I've factored some extra time into the schedule to account for any unexpected delays. 

Once Vivarium is funded I expect the main challenge to be fulfillment. As a first time publisher, this can be very daunting. Which is why I've opted to utilize experienced fulfillment companies with great communication and strong track records. I believe that trusting in the experience of established fulfillment companies and reducing my personal involvement in the process will provide the opportunity to give a stellar service while allowing me to personally learn the ropes for future projects.

Regardless, the estimated delivery time has a buffer of a few months in order to account for any delays or issues that may arise in fulfillment. 

Overall, the main challenges are those of a first time publisher, and by partnering with a tested manufacturer and experienced fulfillment companies the effects of these challenges will be reduced.

If movies have taught us one thing about business, it's that there's only one way to succeed: by firing people for no reason!
With this in mind, we're proud to introduce Downsize, a competitive card game for 2-6 players. Each game, Players command a vast corporation, taking turns to fire employees in order to resolve different effects, whether it's controlling your own workforce, making investments, or influencing your competition.
However, there's only so much money to be made, and as players invest and reap the returns, the market veers closer and closer to collapse. Balance your employees wisely, and liquidate your company before you start incurring losses, to ensure that you end up at the top of the pile.
With Downsize, we wanted to create a game that was as easy to play as it was to set up: one that didn't require players to memorise a lengthy rulebook, but didn't skimp on tactical depth or range.
Downsize takes minutes to learn and play, and is surprisingly addictive, with a level of complexity and strategy that rewards players who take the time to master the game. It's suitable for all ages, and is a great way to make friends - or lose them, depending on how ruthlessly you play.
Contents
The core game comes in a cardboard tuck box, and the cards are machine-cut from professional quality card stock tough enough to withstand more than a few heated games in the  boardroom.
The materials and packaging of the game are subject to change as and when the campaign crosses funding goals, detailed below.
Rewards
Pick your print once we're successfully funded!
 Backers who pay for the Limited Edition Print will receive their choice of 'Department for Motivation' artwork, printed on premium art paper and shipped with a handwritten thank you note from  the game's creator.
The prints bring together 1950's aesthetic with re-worked corporate catchphrases, and are perfect for boardrooms, games rooms, or nurseries.
Funding Goals
As funding for the project passes the above goals, backers who choose the core game perk will have their copy automatically upgraded. 
As we approach the £16,000 mark, we will reveal more information about the 20-card expansion: Market Movements. Once unlocked, the expansion will also be available to Print and Play backers.
Accessibility
During the design process for Downsize, we went to long lengths to ensure that the game was as accessible as possible, in order to rope as many people into our plot for world domination as possible.
As such, we made sure that the game was playable by people with protanopia and deuteranopia colour-blindness, and made the instructions simple and text-light, so that the game is easy to play with little-to-no translation needed if English is not your first language.
Once the campaign is complete, backer surveys will give you the option to indicate a preferred language, and we will endeavour to provide translated rule-sheets and reference cards for the most requested languages on www.BoardGameGeek.com completely free of charge.
Thank You
As with any board game, Downsize is a labour of love: written and designed in lunch breaks and on days off, and put to the test by friends and family in pubs, coffee shops, living rooms - and, in one instance, after Christmas dinner.
A game is as much the property of it's designer as it is the play-testers and Kickstarter backers, so I would like to thank all of you for helping this bizarre, ruthless little game come to life. Happy Playing!

Risks and challenges
So far, we have gone to all possible lengths to ensure that the post-funding period will go as smoothly as possible. We've been in a long dialogue with our manufacturing and shipping teams, and are confident that everything has been brought into consideration.

For your reference, here is a rough guide of what will happen once the project is completed:

Week 1 & 2: The money will be in limbo between Kickstarter and us. During this time, we will send out backer surveys to get your shipping information, preferred prints, and other information.

Week 3 through 5: We will work with the printers to finalise the necessary documents and paperwork, including any unlocked expansions. Your chosen prints will also be processed at this time, and will likely be shipped prior to the games.

Weeks 6-7: The copies of Downsize will be in transit, from the factory, to the distribution warehouse, to you.

The Game Den will open in May 2016. Please to our website or our Facebook page to stay in contact with us and check out our upcoming events. 
Thanks for all of your support throughout the kickstarter. 
The Games Den will be Leamington's only friendly local game store. We want to serve the community that are already playing and show other people why they should be too! And we want to build up relationships with the gamers around Warwickshire so we can take our local teams to the well-established shops in Birmingham and Coventry and Daventry. The kick-starter will really help us hit the ground running with lots of events and a good stock of games. It will also help us start with a wide range of stock, available at the shop or online at gamesdenuk.com
3D Render of the Proposed Games Den Store
 The top priorities in building the shop we want the Games Den to be are;
 • Our commitment to the hobby and to the community. This will impact everything we do and how we do it.
• Our focus on creating an inclusive environment that welcomes a diverse group of gamers.
• Specialist knowledge of boardgames in particular so we can teach and sell them well and recommend different titles.
Schedule of Events
The focus will be on boardgames and card games. We aim to keep a good stock of new and classic boardgame titles as well as remaining up to date with the collectible and living games. We plan to serve those people playing Magic the Gathering, Yu-Gi-Oh! and Pokémon as well as anyone playing Netrunner, Game of Thrones LCG, Lord of the Rings LCG, Doomtown and others. We also intend to stock X-Wing and Armada as well as providing space suited to playing these different titles.
3D Render of the Proposed Games Den Store
The shop also aims to provide a good space to play miniatures games. We will build up a collection of terrain as soon as possible. That way, whether you prefer your futuristic sci-fi optimistic or pessimistic and whether you prefer your fantasy gritty or high classic you’ll have somewhere thematic to play. We don’t intend to hold a lot of stock on opening day but we will sell most of the popular systems on order. We will also pay close attention to the community as it develops and start stocking the products requested most often.
The everyday layout of the shop will seat around 25 people. If events attract more people, maximum comfortable capacity will be around 35 people.
Plan Layout
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The difficulty with location stores is the slow growth in profit. By carefully managing the donations of kick-starter backers and the capital of the owners we can operate the business while allowing the turnover to gradually increase.

In addition, most small companies fail due to cash flow. Dave's experience in stock keeping will allow the company to keep key items stocked while managing costs. By focusing on customer satisfaction, we can also build the group of customers who think of us as their local store.

Hi, I'm Rahdo!
Four years ago, on a whim, I grabbed my iPhone one afternoon and started recording gameplay runthroughs of my favorite board and card games, and uploading them to YouTube. And now I'm about to start my 5th year of filming! WOOHOO!!! 
You can check out my series at
YOUTUBE.COM/RAHDO
As a sampler, here's a playlist of some recent runthroughs I've done (click "playlist" in the top left to see a long list of video choices):
I make these videos primarily for fun, as a way of sharing my enthusiasm and passion for the boardgaming hobby, and helping like-minded board game geeks choose which of the myriad games on the market are right for them. 
But as it happens, as of 2013, I've retired from full-time employment, and now, to be able to continue to produce runthrough videos, I need to raise funds to cover my operating expenses (game purchases, travel expenses to game conventions, and a salary to be able to stay devoted 100% to the show).
Fan Support Makes it all Possible
That's where you come in, because I receive no direct income for Rahdo Runs Through except for fan support in these yearly fund raising drives. I accept no payments from game developers for any game (retail or Kickstarter prototype) that I run through, and I don't turn on YouTube ads (because they're awful), so you folks are truly what keeps Rahdo running through! :)
Just a few of the many games that could be coming soon, with your help...
By backing this, my fourth RAHDO RUNS THROUGH Kickstarter campaign, you're funding my ability to continue to produce videos of all the latest, hottest games, ranging from the big games of the moment like Runebound 3rd Edition and Steam Time, to the soon to be released hits like Pandemic: Reign of Cthulhu and Star Trek Frontiers.
In return for your donation, you have access to a variety of rewards. What are they, you might be wondering?  I'm glad you asked...
THE BACKER REWARDS
Rahdo Runs Through VOTING! Exclusive microbadges!
Custom signed stickers & game bags crocheted with love!
Waterjet meeples and lucky dips galore!
Ogre dice and ogre earrings!
T-shirts!! Represent in sizes S-XXXL with one of the three options shown!
Co-host or direct the show!
Get your game tested! Join a secret society!
MEGA GLASS!!!!
As you can see from these pictures, there's a lot of options for backer rewards in this campaign, and I'm using an a'la carte WILDCARD system to let people choose what combination of them they'd like. 
For more details, here's a quick video where I show/talk about the various rewards and explain how the WILDCARD reward system works:

THE STRETCH GOALS 
Okay, so the target goal for this year basically covers all the new games I'll be acquiring to film, another trip to Essen for more convention coverage and a basic salary for me and Paulo Renato (the fine fellow who fact checks and annotates all my vids... Paulo is l'awesome and keeps me honest!). But, if we go above and beyond the target, below is some additional content that can be provided over the next 12 months!
Stretch Goal #1: Jen Runs Through ($35,000)
Rahdo Runs Through is mostly a one-man show, but people do love it when my lovely wife Jen makes appearances to help me play and demonstrate the games (rather than my normal "virtual" Jen gaming partner!) 
Of course, it's time consuming to film runthroughs, and that takes her away from her actual career of making beautiful glass art. But, if we hit this first stretch goal, Jen will commit to appearing in 12 runthroughs over the course of the year (roughly once each month), and I can tell you right now, the shows she's in are always the most fun to watch! 
To give you an idea of what a Jen-enhanced video is like, here's a playlist of all the videos she's been in to date: http://jen.rahdo.com
Stretch Goal #2: Rahdo Talks Through, the Podcast ($40,000)  
Hitting this stretch goal means I'll continue my monthly Golden Geek Award-nominated podcast series which started last year (no kidding, I almost won an award!!!) where I talk about exciting upcoming games, revisit top10 topics to delve further, and answer plenty of questions (joined each month by Jen).
You can subscribe to the series here: http://podcast.rahdo.com
Stretch Goal #3: Rahdo Runs Through LIVE! ($45,000)
So, last year marked my first foray into the world of YouTube live-casting runthroughs and Q&A sessions, and they seemed to go over very well, with 6 events being aired bi-monthly. There's a fair bit of work in setting these up, but if we hit this stretch goal, I'm up for filming 6 more this year!  
Here's a playlist of last year's live events to see what they're like!
Stretch Goal #4: LeiriaCon! ($50,000)
LeiriaCon is a very popular convention held in Portugal every January, and it just so happens that my fact check/annotations guy Paulo always attends. So if we hit this, I will attend also, cover the convention, and film some video with Paulo, which I think will be a lot of fun. We'll see if he makes as much fun of me in real life! And Jen's schedule permitting, she'll come along as well and get in the team-up videos also!
Stretch Goal #5: Periscope School ($55,000)
A live monthly broadcast via Periscope where I teach Jen (and anyone watching) how to play a new game (see latest update for more details)
"Thanks for watching, talk to you later, so long, buh bye!"

With an hour to go, I thought I'd give the final few people looking at this campaign a reason to back Ember. It's a great monster summoning game; it's a load of fun, with some great laughs as you launch a cunning strategy against your opponents' equally cunning strategy. Plus, it's now got Krampus as a  Legendary Creature - what more can ANYONE possibly ask for? - Stu :)
Update: 110 cards + promo cards all for the bargain price of £13.
Ember is a strategic card game set in a fantasy world of elemental magic. Players collect cards to form “sets” that they cash in to conjure mythical creatures which they can use to boost their abilities or hinder their opponents. It's a race to the finish as the wizards seek glory by collecting the rarest and most powerful creatures.
Update: Ember now has SOLO Play Mode with 13 Curse Cards offered completely free.
48 Hours to Go: Check out our awesome list of Add-Ons (including a t shirt) in the Rewards section.
Here's how Ember fits into the magical world of gaming...
Multiple ways to play: Ember has a variety of different ways to play based on your play-style. Casual Play, Hardcore, or even Battle Mode.
A game of Ember scales based on the number of players; more players equals more creatures which equals more options and strategies.
Plays with 2 to 5 players (best with 4 or 5).
Fantastic Solo Play mode available (with unique Spell cards).
8+ Group Play: Purchase a second Core Set to allow 8 or even 10 to play Ember at the same time. Double the players means double the monsters - no two games will ever be the same! 
The perfect intro game for all the family, based on tried-and-tested mechanics from one of the world's most popular card games. This really is a game you can play with your kids, and they LOVE IT (it's one part Pokemon, one part deck-building game, and one part - take that! - explosive strategy). There are few games out there that scale as well for players of all ages.
Intro Game: Ember is a simple game with lots of depth. You can teach it to just about anyone. It's the perfect light intro game you can play before, after, or even during those heavier games. 
Many Ways to Play: With a bunch of ways to play, Ember is fantastic value. Try Casual, Hardcore, and Solo modes.

campaign.story:
In a metal-riveted palace, covered in a heavy layer of coal dust, lies the Steam Court. In this 1–12 player card game, players act as engineers attempting to build machines (take tricks of cards) in order to impress the Queen and her royal court. The Courtiers grant their Engineers unique privileges, which players can use as they work their way up the social ladder and collect victory point gears.
Check out our quick gameplay overview in the How-to-Play section or watch our fully-steampunked-walk-through-video and see exactly how it's done.
Each copy of Steam Court will come with the following geartastic components:
Pledge at one of the following levels and you'll receive this great stuff! We're happy to accommodate special requests as well. Let us know!
ROYAL COINS ADD-ON
We have introduced metallic coins into the mix! This add-on will automatically be given to our backers at the Chancellor level and above. If you would like to add the 6 metal coins to another pledge level, simply increase your pledge by $9 for each set. The custom-made coins will be poured solid metal and shaped to match the first 6 numbered tokens in the game. They will be approximately 1 inch in diameter.
RENEGADES COINS ADD-ON (KICKSTARTER EXCLUSIVE)Several of you have asked, so we've worked it out with our Coin Artisan and are excited to announce that we'll be offering another set of 6 coins "covered in a heavy layer of coal dust," for the Renegades table! They will match the mold of the Royal coins, but will feature a patina finish. These are not automatically included with the Chancellor Level, so you'll need to add $9 to your pledge level and note which coins you want on the survey at the end of the campaign.
Each time we reach a new stretch goal we will release a video detailing the stuff that we'll achieve if we reach the NEXT level. Help us make Steam Court everything it has the potential to be!

We've greatly appreciated the feedback, insight and critiques that all of our friends, playtesters and even our frenemies, have shared with us. Steam Court wouldn't be what it is without you. Thanks much!
                                                                                         Here's a review in Italian!
Super quick overview: Players randomly select a character token and seat themselves in order from the highest character to the lowest. Once the gears are dealt and characters exercise their special privileges, the highest player at the table (Queen) starts the first trick. She can lay any quantity of cards of the same value (e.g. three 3s). The next player needs to lay the same quantity of matching cards, but of a higher value.
What's Unique:
"TRICK TAKING"—Steam Court is a ladder trick-taking game, that plays over four rounds of cards (Quarters). Each Quarter, players rotate seats (and privileges) based on who managed to play all of their cards first.
"CHARACTER ABILITIES"—Each Courtier grants his engineer a special privilege (well.. if you can call having to shuffle, deal, and give away your best cards the Tea Boy's "privileges"). These privileges generally benefit a player and give him special opportunities during the game.
"VICTORY POINTS"—Each time a player plays all of his cards he garners a numbered gear token. Unlike traditional card games, at the end of Steam Court the player with the most points on his gear tokens wins!
"PARTY PLAY"—We've written a rule variant which allows players to come and go each Quarter throughout the game. If you are looking for a party game then ditch the gear tokens, determine a number of Quarters and whoever is engineer to the Queen at the end, wins!
"SOLO PLAY"—Thanks to your support we've been able to add a solo variant as well. Play 1-player vs. the Court Hand in this solitaire trick-taking game.
"12 PLAYERS"—How many other games do you know that support 12 players? How many?
Click on the instruction manual below for details on all of these unique game elements, or click the video to view a walk-through.
Shipping to the states is included in the pledge level. Shipping charges to Australia ($12), Canada ($7), and the EU ($12) are available add-ons. We are EU friendly if you back at the $29 reward level. The $49 reward level requires us to sign your box which means it will be shipped from the United States to you. If you live elsewhere, we'd love to be able to get the game out to you, and can give you a personal quote if you want to send us a message. International shipping can be a challenge, but if you are interested, we will figure out a way to get it into your hands. Thanks for understanding and being awesome enough to ask us about it!
We couldn't have made it this far without them. And we can't take the next step without you! Please consider backing our project. We have high hopes for what's in store for the future.

*Feel free to skip this section if you are a previous CTG game owner. 
More than a few of you are SHOCKED as you search in vain for what you guessed would be a $50-65 base backer level only to find out things start at $98! Allow us to build some appreciation for the VALUE found in this $98 backer level. 
First, a little about Chip Theory Games. If you are actually reading this than you are probably fairly new to our games. Those that have backed us before, own something in our Hoplo series, or have played our games at conventions, automatically understand what's up. So first, let us give you a chance to hear from some of those people who, like you, may wince at the $98 price tag but also know its worth every penny. Check them out here.    
If that didn't convince you, lets take a look at what is actually in this game. 
5 Die-cut Neoprene Play mats - Some may think neoprene is all the same...those "some" would be very wrong. Print quality, fabric type, neoprene composition, and thickness can all make or break the outcome. Print quality is an obvious one due to the fact that poor quality on neoprene results in dark, muddy images. Fabric type wasn't so important for Hoplo but is extremely important for Bones because you have dice rubbing on the fabric edges every time you lock or use a die. Composition is what determines elasticity and will help keep the dice in place. So what is a good, 10" x 9" die-cut mat worth? $10? $12? X5?
34 11.5g Unit chips and 65 Health chips - Neoprene and chips go together like bread and butter. This duo is what makes CTG special. Each chip has a weight plug set inside it to give it that substantial feel. The sticker is actually a 2-part foil and hard plastic overlay that makes the images pop yet protects it from water drops or spills (if you want to see a funny video series on our Hoplo mats - check it out here). Our health chips are lighter and are all one mold imprinted with our logo. Much more elaborate in comparison to other game tokens. All your Baddie stats are right there on the chip. Value? Tons!
83 Game Cards (Encounters, Loot, Troves, Bosses) - Even now as I list all of this I feel the need to go back and make sure we factored certain things into our game price! ;) Cards are a new one for us but you can be sure we won't disappoint! 
130 Custom-sided Dice (100+ unique) - I feel like this kind of speaks for itself, but in case it doesn't, then here are a few things to  keep in mind. Dice size, imaging process, and cornering/tumbling process can all affect the quality outcome. We have an insane amount of dice art that includes very small numbers and multiple colors. The need for a quality process that can give us all of these things, can really affect the price of these dice! 
Everything else - I'll spare you the rest of the details on our box, our dice tray molds, high-quality rulebook printing, etc. But just ask a Hoplo owner and they will confirm that we try to think of everything including what else might go in the box, what trays could be used outside the box and so on. 
Ok, our VALUE pitch is over! :) If you are still not convinced, its ok! Thank you for getting this far and for checking out the campaign to begin with. For those who remain...we aim to impress and dare not disappoint! 
Too Many Bones is a 1-4 player Solo/Co-op RPG Adventure using dice to shape and implement your battle strategies. Game length is decided by the Boss tyrant you choose to confront and can range from 60-90 mins.
Sample Boss Card
You start your journey as a Gearloc in the town of Obendar, fighting one battle a day as you progress north toward the tyrant you are trying to take out. The goal is earn enough Progress points by completing Encounters/Daily Battles to reach the Boss Tyrant and trigger the final battle. You must achieve this within a set number of days shown on that tyrant. 
Each day provides you with a new Encounter that will affect your next battle. Based on what you choose, you may gain very specific rewards or you may have to forfeit them to allow your party a better chance of success. Every Encounter card and the choices within can change from one game to the next due to how enemies are introduced into your battles. 
Sample Encounter 1
Sample Encounter 2
Sample Encounter 3
Battles scale with your day counter and party size and is where all the action happens! A battle consists of determining and drawing enemies based on your total Baddie Strength. Your party then faces off against these opponents in an awesome dice-rolling battle! For example, if your party size is 2 and it is day 4, you multiply those together to get your Baddie Strength for that day's battle. However, before drawing those enemies, you must also check to see if your Encounter card alters those points. If not, you would be drawing, a 5-point Baddie, and 3 1-point Baddies. 
If your total ends up filling more than 4 slots, the other Baddies are staged next to the Battle mat and fill empty spots immediately (but start at 1 initiative).
8 Baddie Strength Points
Battle Mat with Initiative Meter 
Using your neoprene Character Mats and your unlocked stat and skills, you will decide which attack, defense, and skill dice to roll each round. Based on those rolls, you will then execute attacks, perform blocks, utilize your backup plan, or save dice for the next round.
Boomer's Character Mat with unlocked Skill Dice
Character Skill Dice (16 skill dice and 1 initiative die)
Basic Defense Dice
*The Attack and Defense dice shown in the full component list as well as our videos are prototype. The actual Atk and Def dice will have different color backgrounds so you can quickly tell them apart. This is true of both our White dice (for the Gearlocs) and Black dice (for the Baddies).   
Character Skill Dice
When the dust settles and you are on top, you will gain progress points, increase your stat and skill trees, and often you are able to loot your enemies to better equip yourselves for your next encounter.
As you continue to complete encounters, your skill dice pool grows and eventually you will have earned enough Encounter points to trigger the Boss Tyrant battle! Defeating him will win you the game! 
 Find out more about our Award-winning Hoplo Series HERE!
So how do our Add-ons work? Just total up the items you would like to add and tack that amount on to your pledge for now. We will clarify everything in the survey after the campaign ends! *NOTE: Tink and Ghillie are both included in the BONES - FULL PARTY pledge level. Also, in order to pledge for Add-ons, you need to be pledging for the game itself.
Add-on Shipping: Each Add-on increases the weight and cost to ship (we also must pay an extra fee for each SKU we add to an order). We have set the shipping cost at $2 per Add-on. However, to encourage Add-on purchases AND to give people a further break on shipping, Adam and I are willing to subsidize (fully cover) the extra shipping for Add-ons if you order 3 or more. There are a total of 5 Add-ons you can choose from below (not counting Tink or Ghillie). *The BONES - FULL PARTY level already grants a discount for Tink and Ghillie and are not considered "Add-ons" at the FULL PARTY level.
Note on Premium Health - this is added to your game. You will still receive the original 65 logo-molded health chips. 
Note on the Liberation Logbook: Some of the details are still being worked out with this book since we want it to contain images of every one of our Baddies, Tyrants, and Gearlocs! Because this number is growing quickly...the book is getting more and more expen...valuable! :) The cost will stay at $25 but the details on printing material, binding, etc, need to be left open-ended due to these constant changes. 
Here is what we know for sure each book will contain: 
Artwork in various sizes of all completed Baddies and Tyrants (like you see in the example).
Artwork and concept/development art for all 7 Gearlocs (like you see in the example above). 
A series of 7 (but probably more) short stories from the perspective of our Gearlocs, while on their adventure to the north. 
Signatures from both Jim (writer), Anthony (artist), as well as Adam and myself.
Beyond that, our intention was to give this a very loose feel, as if they were page singles written in haste, constantly gathered, and transported in a binder of sorts. This part we cannot commit to just yet. We need to see what comes of how much art and story we are fitting in this thing! I'm sure you understand! 
Note on the Adventure Map: There are 2 counters to this mat. The first is a glass bead that comes with the mat. This follows the paths on your map to track progress. The other counter is the Day Counter Chip (at 200k funding). This chip fits easily into the die-cut area in the bottom right corner of your map and tracks your days. 
When you draw a Tyrant and set it next to the mat, this card will show the days and progress this adventure must be completed in. This will correspond with one of the 3 destinations on the map (each destination is a set amount of progress points away from Obendar and our Tyrants all adhere to one of those amounts). So, for instance, The Goblin King is an 8 progress Tyrant, which means he has taken up residence at Warspire. This location is on the map at 8 progress points from Obendar and is now your destination for this adventure. 
All 3 locations must cross the Sibron river which is reached at 3 Encounters into any adventure. The map shows this very clearly and is a nice visual reminder that battles are now going to get harder. 
Also, this mat makes Extended Campaigns much easier. An Extended Campaign is one where you attempt to clear not just one region but two or three! Once you complete your first location, it will grant you X progress to your second destination and you must backtrack to a split that will take you further north. An extended campaign can easily be done without this map, its just not quite as immersive.
To be clear, this map is not necessary to play TMB. Drawing the Tyrant card and step-stacking completed Encounter cards showing earned progress underneath - works great. That being said, this map really gives you a FEEL for where you are headed and helps you visualize the encounters you are facing and where they are happening within the story.

In Too Many Bones, you are playing as an unusual race of adventurers headed into a land overrun by all sorts of hostile creatures. Your race has lived hidden in the Deepwood for centuries and only recently, your kin have been forced to emerge to the south and take shelter within the walls of Obendar. 
Due to your reclusive lifestyle, many in town are encountering your race for the very first time. Some in town believe you to be an elf, due to your distinct facial features; others, would say a goblin, from your size and build. Others still, would insist your high technological aptitude proves you a gnome! Only those most intimate with the Deepwood, know your true kind and kin as: Gearlocs. Big-eared, thin-bodied creatures with a conflicting love of nature and machine, and overall, an insatiable thirst for adventure! 
The elder Gearlocs, know all too well that this growing danger to the north is the work of the Ebon, a melting pot of lawless creatures ruled by tyrants, each with a firm grasp on all the northern regions of Daelore. Because each of these regions has little to no communication with the next, it is the elders belief that a smaller party will be most effective and will draw the least attention. They have selected your party of adventurers and have tasked them with venturing northward to silence the Ebon one tyrant at a time. 
This was never to be your task alone! Others were sequestered, but the Obendar militia is thin in ranks and any sellswords worth hiring, have already been swayed by the promise of plundering rights to aid the enemy. But no matter! For you are Gearlocs! And being the resourceful and fearless race that you are, your party has happily accepted this adventure! You will be among the first to travel north in many decades and your adventure begins today!
Why is International shipping so much!?
Many of you may be shocked by our international shipping costs for the project (especially those who are new to our heavy CTG projects). First of all, this is par for the course when shipping 11.5 gram chips, thick neoprene mats, and 130 (currently) custom dice! As we have mentioned, this box is over 8 lbs! If you reference our last project and scroll to the bottom, we posted a shipping breakdown. Hoplo: Origins is about half the weight of Bones and you can see that as the rest of our lineup is added, prices go up significantly. Its the nature of the beast with shipping heavy boxes. After all of that, we still took a hit on shipping internationally!
The HUGE difference is that in our Origins campaign, international backers were getting hit hard by VAT/Customs fees on top of our shipping rates. Our goal for this project was to wipe those out by covering the VAT fees ourselves for EU and Canada through bulk shipments to those countries. 
Because its our first time dealing with EU and Canada-Friendly shipping, the "Friendly" part is strictly a savings on those customs and VAT fees. We are continually getting quotes and trying to reduce international shipping FURTHER for our backers.
How can your shipping be considered EU and Canada "Friendly"?
As stated earlier, EU and Canada Friendly means the products are shipped to you directly from those countries. It doesn't mean shipping is automatically free or greatly discounted (though those things often accompany such a claim). What it DOES mean: What you pay for shipping now, is it. There is nothing tacked on later, no hidden extra fees. *Handling things up front also means that we are using those shipping fees paid to increase our total pledge amount - thus getting to Stretch Rewards for you significantly faster. 
Covering the customs and VAT fees is a major step for us. Adam and I have spent a lot of time getting our feet wet in this area and it was a big decision to go this route at all as it means securing international fulfillment and bulk transport when up to this point Adam and I have been rolling up our sleeves and relying primarily on each other to make all of this magic happen. Don't get me wrong, we are not slouches! Hoplo is proof of that! But with all your support, you are helping CTG grow up! This is one of the growing pains. So while we'd love to subsidize huge amounts of the shipping like projects that have 1000+ backers...please understand our best project had 333. It makes these types of deals a bit more tricky/costly to work though.
You are buying a PREMIUM GAME from us. For $100+ it sure as heck better be! So besides trying to add another layer of QC, there are components slated for this game that are done locally along with much of the game assembly, thus making it virtually impossible to ship these to their destinations directly from Asia. This is still being worked through and obviously we hope to improve on things. 
So, given those constraints, our goals remain: 1) We wipe out VAT and customs fees - done. 2) We drop the game cost as low as we possibly can ($120 MRSP for $98 on KS) - done. 3) We quote and requote as many International shipping options as we can, using people and campaigns that have done it successfully in the past (not just appearing to have done it by subsidizing a ton and losing their shirts)! And hopefully, by the end of the campaign, we can improve on the posted rates. But if we can't, at least you will know why. 
Anyone can "offer" free or greatly reduced shipping. But you know its not..."free"...someone is paying for it. You will often find it worked right back into the cost of the game itself or tacked on later. If it is actually free or discounted to YOU, then the margin or backer count on that game must be quite impressive. Sadly, with our commitment to no less than the best components, that impressive margin doesn't exist for us. We are ok with that as long as we can show that quality to our backers and produce amazing games in the process.
To those who feel shipping is still too much of a hurdle, we completely understand! Hopefully you can get in on things after we have some inventory established internationally (another great benefit of going the "Friendly" route for us = excess inventory already staged in those countries after KS fulfillment). 
Thanks for all the feedback thus far! We WILL update everyone before the campaign ends if there are any changes or reductions!

Risks and challenges
Every new Kickstarter is an opportunity to improve on the last. We have now run 3 successful KS campaigns and delivered on every one. Our challenges have always stemmed from the fact that we are still a fairly small company. In the past 3 years we have grown our help and connections to a point where now, for the first time, we are able to take on some more advanced assembly and fulfillment solutions both in the US and abroad! 

Our biggest challenge will be to see these new initiatives through! These include: US Order Fulfillment (no longer just Adam and I), EU Friendly shipping, and Canada Friendly shipping. Rest assured we won't stop there! But we need more quantity to be able to go beyond this. 

For those who are new to Chip Theory Games, risks are low and if you talk to anyone that owns one of our games, we are quite certain they will tell you the same thing. You can pledge with confidence that you will receive a high quality product that is well worth the price.

Greetings from the Chip Theory Command Center!
It's been a whirlwind couple of weeks for us. You've probably seen us mention in the comments that Adam and Josh (and their respective families) caught a *really* nasty flu bug that knocked each of them flat for roughly a week and a half. Not sure there could have been worse timing with the new website launch and games finally arriving in US backers' hands at that exact moment, but it is what is. Everyone is on the mend now, and we're working hard to catch up.
Shipping Update!

Hey everybody!
Apologies if we've seemed less active here over the last week. The CTG team and our families have been hit with a nasty case of viral poison, and we're still waiting for the poison counter to tick down to zero before fully jumping back into battle.
We see the anticipation and anxiety on all of our social channels regarding shipping, so we wanted to give you the latest to (hopefully) ease your mind a bit. We want to preface all of this by simply reminding you that literally nobody wants you to have your game more than us! We've labored over every part of Too Many Bones for more hours than you can imagine. Breathe deep and grab an orcish ale while you wait, it will be in your hands soon.

Special Announcement! We have a Campaign Mode in the works!
You asked for it! We've been holding details of this pretty close to the vest, but we are excited to show you the first glimpses of Campaign Mode for Too Many Bones.  Early testing confirmed one thing very quickly, after about 3 Tyrants, you're going to have your character pretty much maxed out. This obviously makes it difficult as the Day Counter climbs higher and higher, making the baddies tougher and tougher.

The core rulebook for Robert E. Howard’s Conan: Adventures in an Age Undreamed Of is a 368 page full colour hardcover book containing everything you’ll need to adventure in the world of Robert E. Howard’s hero, Conan. It is based entirely on the canonical Conan stories, and uses the 2D20 system developed by Modiphius and used in Mutant Chronicles 3rd Edition, Infinity, John Carter Warlord of Mars and other fine games. This tome presents character generation, the game’s rules, and a wealth of source material, including cultures, geography, religions, magic, gods, monsters, gamemastering advice, adventure seeds, and much more. This work has been developed by an all-star writing team, with close involvement by respected Robert E. Howard authorities, and is illustrated by world-renowned Conan artists. 
All the supplements will also be in beautiful full colour hardback and describe the world in additional detail, presenting different styles of play from the phases of Conan’s saga... Thief, Barbarian, Mercenary, Pirate, the Unknown East, Brigand, Kingdoms of the South, Scout... and King. Other books will explore sorcery, monsters and demons, nameless cults, secret societies and fighting orders, distant lands, ancient ruins, and lost cities. The game line will be supported with a wide range of ready-to-play adventures and campaigns spanning the breadth of Conan’s world.
The 2d20 system is a dynamic, narrative system, designed to produce varied and interesting results from dramatic and action-packed situations. Characters roll two d20s, attempting to roll as low as possible on each one – the more dice that roll low, the more successes the character scores.You can download the Quickstart complete with introductory rules, adventure and pre-generated characters from DriveThruRPG

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
With big projects like this there are lots of people involved. Writers, artists, editors, rules designers, layout artists, proof readers, logistics, finance, warehouses, and more. People often have problems - it's just part of life and this can cause delays. When this happens we do the best we can to help - moving workload to someone else, finding a replacement, getting more people involved, or moving things around in the schedule to allow them more time. Modiphius is a family owned company (Chris & Rita) and we know that most people working on games like this do it for the love, not the salaries so we work hard to make it as supportive an environment as possible. 

There are always issues to deal with no matter how well you prepare - perhaps a supplier's moulds break and need several weeks to replace, perhaps a printer gets flooded destroying some stock they just spent a month printing, deliveries can go missing, data can be collected in such a way that it causes problems with fulfilment, and so on. 

We have run 4 major Kickstarter's now so are familiar with a lot of the possible problems and do our best to prepare. Modiphius has expanded adding two people who help analyse data and plan logistics with the various companies we use to ship out our rewards across the world. We've learnt from our mistakes and taken steps to simplify how we run Kickstarters at every step possible. 

Even so we allow more time 'just in case' and we work hard to ensure everyone queries are answered in a timely manner. Modiphius has one of the best reputations for customer service. When things do go wrong we are open and transparent. We try to find a fair solution for everyone. 

You can check out out previous Kickstarters for Achtung! Cthulhu, Mutant Chronicles 3rd Edition Roleplaying Game and Thunderbirds Co-Operative Boardgame to see how happy people are with their rewards. We have completed shipping 12 books and lots of merchandising for Achtung! Cthulhu. Mutant Chronicles has had over 70% of shipments across 7 books with lots of accessories and a further 20% of pledges with 7 books have started shipping this month. The first shipment of Thunderbirds pledges shipped only 2 weeks late and the final shipment will be despatched the middle of next month. 

With each of these projects we have a different team of writers, artists, editors and layout designers so one project's schedules (or delays) doesn't affect another. We also have many other games we have published (or co-published) including the award winning Mutant: Year Zero, Dust Adventures, Mindjammer, Fragged Empire and Symbaroum. 

Conan has some particular issues we are bearing in mind: 

- All products will need to be approved by Conan Properties LLC. We have a great relationship with them though, and they have loved everything we have done so far so I don't foresee any problems here. With Jeff Shanks involvement we are effectively ensuring everything we produce for Conan is about as true to the spirit of Robert E. Howard as possible. 

- We're using major name artists for each of the main books in the line. They can have demanding schedules and if they are delayed delivering a book cover to us by a previous project over-running then that could affect the timetable. We do have a number of covers we're commissioning that could work for several different books, so in the event one cover is delayed we can likely substitute another cover in it's place by an equally amazing artist.

A “fair division algorithm” sounds pretty dry, but it turns out, it’s a great way to start making a game.
For a while, my friend and game designer mentor Kory Heath had been working on different games that involve, essentially, taking a pile of stuff and dividing them up. One of the simpler forms of this is “I cut, you choose” where one player divides stuff up into two piles, and the other player chooses which one to take (usually, the player doing the dividing gets the leftover, which is what makes it fair.)
While Kory was making mostly card games, one version I helped him playtest involved rolling a pile of dice with different colored sides, and dividing those using the following method:
When it’s your turn, you must do one of the following things: take any number of dice from the center and put it in front of you, or steal the set that someone else has taken. If you do, you must return at least one die to the center.
Then go to the next person, who has the same options, until only one person doesn’t have a set. They can either steal as normal, or take everything remaining in the center. In this way, everything will end up taken by someone.
For various reasons, his version didn’t work. For one, it was TOO fair for what you were trying to do under the simple scoring system. Shortly after some playtests at a game design retreat, he moved back towards card games.
Years later, I remembered that prototype, and how much I enjoyed that core idea. With his blessing I decided to take my own crack at using dice with that “steal and reduce” system.  I knew that I needed something that had less of a chance of being too fair, where you didn’t know the exact value of each die. Additionally, in order to make sure there was a little more variation in rounds, I added a rule that when you steal another pile and return dice to the center, the die you threw back was rerolled. In that way, the set of dice you start the round with isn’t always what you end up with. It even means that if the first player hates the initial roll, they can take EVERYTHING from the center, forcing someone to steal from them and reroll some of the dice.
These tweaks proved to be successful, as did including a Start Player marker in the set of dice to add extra texture. However, the real problem remained: what do you do with the dice once you have them, and how do you make it interesting?
I tested different versions using tried and true scoring methods: majorities, area control, set collection, even a train game. None hit the mark until I returned to that same game design retreat. Playing other published games and talking with game designers was how I hit on the idea of making a center tableau of cards for purchase that cost different combinations of colors. Those cards in turn could be “engine” cards instead of just scoring methods. Turn one die into another kind. Turn dice into points. Buy extra cards on your turn. And so on.
When figuring out all the possibilities of card costs I decided to make only four sides of the dice used to buy cards, so the other two could be special. One became a “delayed Wild” (tokens that could be spent on future turns) and the other straight up Points.
The first prototype under this system I called “Spell Dice” since I used Magic Set Editor (software designed to create new Magic: the Gathering cards) to make it and it came with its own magical layout. Each card was a different magic item, so for instance the cards that scored in pairs became Magic Boots.
I knew I had something from the first playtest. Players would know what cards were available to decide what they should value, and needed to balance between being too greedy and not capitalizing enough from each roll. There were decisions points to go for a specific card and strategy, or just bank Wilds and Points for future turns to stay adaptable. Once it was clear that players were going for a specific track, it became easier to tell which dice they cared about. 
I took the game on a tour of various game design conventions, including Metatopia, Unpub, and smaller events. It quickly became clear that the theme wasn’t connecting: it didn’t feel like you were casting spells and magic items didn’t do what they sounded like. The next version I went Full Euro: the dice were resources like bricks and grain and the cards were different buildings you add to your village.
That was closer: the variety of card names connected to players easier. I had been showing it as “Village Dice,” but that was giving players the impression it was closer to a light, short game ala Zombie Dice and Martian Dice, when it’s a 45 minute-ish strategy game. It then became “Market Square” for the next set of conventions, where it caught the attention of Tasty Minstrel Games, and we made the agreement for them to publish it. During development, we talked about changing it into a fantasy theme to fit into the same world as one of their other great games, Harbour.
Instead of splitting resources, you were thieves splitting up the loot, and then using it to acquire various valuables, hideouts, and henchmen (such as a Gauntlet of Evil Intent or an Anthromorphic Water Buffalo) to increase your abilities and status as a thief. It has returned to the fantasy/magic theme, but in a way much more connected, with great names for the cards. It’s also gained a criminal side, which given two of my previous games (Criminals and Heat) is marking me as a shady character of the game design world.
Other than continuing to refine the game through more playtesting there was one more important step for me: I showed the near finished game to Kory Heath, who had created the core mechanism and inspired the whole thing. After the first game, he had just one word for me: Publish!
Thank you so much for taking the time to look through our project, and Thank You for Backing...it's because of You we get to keep bringing great games to your table.

campaign.story:
Not long after the original Jane Austen's Matchmaker Kickstarter had funded, I started to get requests for a ‘zombie’ expansion. Well... here it is!
This expansion consists of 50 new cards and rules to supplement the original game.
You must still make advantageous marriages for your ladies and gentleman but now with the inconvenience of an undead apocalypse which threatens to make a bloody mess of your wedding plans. One player starts the game afflicted with the Curse of the Living Dead.
The Cursed player draws cards from the new deck - both on their own turn and when anyone gets married. This deck includes many Zombie cards, which transform the Cursed player's ladies and gentlemen into flesh-eating monsters! If the player runs out of characters to infect, they must pass the Curse onto someone else.
Gift cards send useful items to other players - including weapons and the means to protect themselves from zombie attacks. Event cards may unleash a horde of ravenous Zombies on polite society or help the poor survivors to persevere with their essential tea-drinking and courtship.
It is very difficult for the Cursed player to win, but not impossible - if they can keep their Zombies well-fed with a stocked up Slaughter pile...
I realise that many Austen purists might consider this expansion an abomination in more ways than one. Jane obviously didn't have much patience with gothic novels, which she gently mocks in Northanger Abbey. It was a year after her death that Mary Shelley's Frankenstein was published, so we’ll probably never know her opinions on the ‘living dead’. But if the very idea of her works combined with zombies makes you hot under the collar, I’d cordially invite you to consider Jane Austen’s Matchmaker in its original composition and put all thoughts of flesh-eating monsters from your mind.

campaign.story:
We are going to come back with a magical re-launch on 16th March 2016 at noon GMT. We made a few rookie mistakes with this campaign and we can do better.
Thank you for your support :)
EMBER
Midnight at the Arcane Academy, yet the apprentice wizards are not in their beds; they have slipped away to a campfire in the woods, far away from prying eyes. There, huddled around the flames, the young wizards play a game. Someone has stolen a mote of elemental true flame from the Artificer’s Vault, which the wizards will cast into the moon-drenched sky and enchant with their magic. Whoever transforms the mote into the most powerful mythical creature is the winner. This is Ember.
The CORE GAME contains
52 x Character Wizards (play deck)
30 x Creature Cards*
1 x Vorpal Bunny (Promo Card - Stretch Goal)
6 x Archmage cards
*This number will change depending on our fabulous Stretch Goals.
Ember is a simple, intro game that can be played in just ten to 15 minutes with plenty of replayability and different strategies for everyone. It's bright and colourful and appeals to pretty much anyone who likes card games. What better way to introduce our company, District 31 to the world than with a super simple, fun magical game about conjuring mythical creatures?
It's a trick-taking game with magical creatures. What more can anyone ask for?
These cards are just art prototypes - we'll offer upgraded art if we reach our funding goal (we have many exciting plans for the art which YOU can have your say in).
THE RULES
Ember's rules are super simple. It's designed as an entry level game that anyone can enjoy (with added levels of complexity for extra magic).

Download the Ember Rules Page 1 and Ember Rules Page 2 
It will be one lovely document in the finished full-colour booklet :)
We have plenty of stretch goals planned and a slew of new and exciting cards. The stretch goals will initially focus on much nicer quality products, but future goals will include loads and loads of lovely juicy new cards. Elementastic! 
Facebook Likes: https://www.facebook.com/District31UK
Check out Ember on BoardGameGeek: 
Shipping for Ember is heavily subsidized. It's only £2 to anywhere in the UK and considerably cheaper than the standard Royal Mail to ship anywhere else in the world. We already have a retail outlet so we're really good at packing your precious goodies!
Listed here are the costs for the game including the basic art and the printing. If we are fortunate enough to overfund, stretch goals will see a telescopic box, gorgeous linen cards, and some really exciting art.
These figures are based on the £4000 goal we need.
While we've already done most of the art for Ember, we want to take our next game much more seriously in terms of promotion. So we need to get the art started right now so we can ship to people like Undead Viking - among others - we're not going miss the smaller guys, either - we love yooooouuuu toooooo :D
We have four other games in development - but we really do need funds to get them started (have you seen how expensive minis are to sculpt?)...
The wizards at District 31 have over thirty years' experience in professional publishing, having worked in all forms of media and publishing in a wide variety of industries. Stu has been an in-print columnist for over two decades, and has worked on Dungeons & Dragons, White Wolf's Scarred Lands, the Doctor Who RPG, as well as a slew of other products - we are no strangers to in-print releases and - even more importantly - providing quality products!         
We've already got a retail / fulfilling network established from our retail outlet, so our packing golems can easily manage to ship the games on the week of release. We'll also be selling all our own products from there - but more on that later.
On the delivery date. Like Scotty fixing the Warp Core, we like to over-perform, so we've given you an overly conservative delivery date that we're sure you'll be delighted when Ember turns up on your doorstep in May 2016.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
There is only one risk with this project (other than the unfortunate demise of the developers to alien invasion*) and that is if the printer doesn't manage to print the cards by the agreed printing date. We have arranged a window with the printer, but we have not used this particular company before and although the quality is exceptional, there is a risk that they will not meet their targets, in which case, this game will not be shipped until July 2016. 

That said, we are going to visit the printer when we print so we can ensure we get the best possible print with the most vibrant colours and that everything is as perfect as it can possibly be. YAY road trip!

We have done everything possible to ensure a smooth process and have arranged for mitigation plans, but we cannot control every third party problem and we know problems do occur. That said, we do not anticipate any problems with Ember. We have ensured adequate third party checks on the products are carried out and we may even go to visit the printers while they are printing to verify the condition of the product as they are printing.

*We'd like to state here and now that we are all most decidedly probe-phobic! Except for Chris. He's decidedly open to the experience!

OK. Stop reading now and go PLEDGE!!! :D
